p: Because gloves—like many medical objects—are enacted within relationally dense and profoundly affective practices, they project a multiplicity of different imaginaries, meanings, and uses, often simultaneously. Such meetings of radically different realities are not, by definition, problematic. However, this ontological multiplicity can create opportunities for viral transmission. As in the case of the twin village, it is in its capacity to mark out the emergence and convergence of difference within a shared landscape—or in this case, within the same object—that the hotspot gains its analytical traction.
